action.action-desc: Mr. Smucker (for himself and Mr. Davis of North Carolina) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Education and the Workforce

form.official-title: To direct the Secretary of Health and Human Services to develop and nationally disseminate accurate, relevant, and accessible resources to promote understanding about sensitivities regarding adoption in the health care industry, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Hospital Adoption Education Act of 2023.

paragraph.text: 24 percent of Americans say that they have considered adopting a child.
81 percent of birth parents report that easy access to objective information is important to them when making the decision to choose adoption.
93 percent of Americans consider hospitals and health care facilities to be trustworthy sources of information about adoption.
98.2 percent of nurses have no professional development in the sensitivities around adoption.
Only 4 percent of women with unintended pregnancies place their children through adoption.

section.header: Development and dissemination of adoption resources

subsection.text: The Secretary of Health and Human Services—

paragraph.text: shall develop and nationally disseminate accurate, relevant, and accessible resources to promote understanding about—

subparagraph.text: the sensitivities regarding adoption in the health care industry; and
best practices when interacting with prospective birth mothers and adoptive families; and

paragraph.text: in carrying out paragraph (1)—

subparagraph.text: may include other types of resources, such as print resources.

subsection.header: Online adoption resources for health care workers
subsection.text: The Secretary shall maintain on the public website of the Administration for Children and Families a webpage on adoption resources for health care workers to improve the awareness and understanding of such workers regarding adoption.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall develop the resources required by subsections (a) and (b) through a committee of adoption experts.
The membership of the committee referred to in paragraph (1) shall include—

subparagraph.text: representatives of organizations involved in adoption education;

section.header: Education and professional development for care providers regarding patient care for families pursuing adoption, including prospective birth mothers and potential adoptive families

subsection.text: The Secretary, acting through the Administration for Children and Families, directly or through grants or contracts in accordance with subsection (b), shall—

paragraph.text: provide to care providers at hospitals and birthing centers education and professional development regarding patient care for families pursuing adoption, including prospective birth mothers and potential adoptive families; and

provide consultation services to hospitals and birthing centers employing care providers on standardized policies, guidelines, and procedures regarding such education and professional development for such care providers

subsection.text: If the Secretary chooses to provide education, professional development, or consultation services under subsection (a) through the award of a grant or contract, the following provisions shall apply:

paragraph.text: To be eligible for such an award, an entity—

subparagraph.text: shall be a health care-based education organization that focuses on adoption; and

paragraph.text: To seek such an award, an eligible entity shall submit an application to the Secretary at such time, in such manner, and containing such information and assurances as the Secretary may require.
The period of such an award shall not exceed 3 fiscal years.

As a condition on receipt of such an award, an eligible entity shall agree to submit to the Secretary each fiscal year a report on the activities carried out through the award. Each such report shall include such information as the Secretary determines is necessary to provide an accurate description of such activities.

Activities carried out using funds made available through such an award shall supplement, and not supplant, activities carried out using other funds made available from the Federal Government or other sources.
provide technical assistance to eligible entities regarding activities carried out through an award under this section; and

as appropriate, coordinate the provision of education, professional development, and consultation services under subsection (a) with other adoption-related research, professional development, services, and assistance activities carried out by the Department of Health and Human Services.
The Secretary shall evaluate the implementation and effectiveness of the activities carried out (directly or through grants or contracts) under this section, including by calculating—

subparagraph.text: the number of hospitals and birthing centers that implement adoption-sensitive programming and education and professional development as a result of the activities under this section; and
the number of care providers who receive adoption education or professional development as a result of the activities under this section.

paragraph.text: Not later than 3 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall complete the evaluation under paragraph (1) and submit to the Congress a report that contains the results of such evaluation, including the calculations under subparagraphs (A) and (B) of paragraph (1).
The term birth mother means a woman who places her baby with the adoptive parents and terminates parental rights.

The term care provider includes any health care personnel (including bedside staff) and ancillary staff who have contact in a hospital or birthing center with expectant mothers, birth mothers, and potential adoptive families.

The term child-placing agency means a business or service conducted, maintained, or operated by a person engaged in finding homes for newborn infants by placing, or arranging for the placement of, such newborn infants for adoption or foster care.
The term potential adoptive family means one or more individuals who are actively seeking to adopt a child.
The term Secretary means the Secretary of Health and Human Services.

section.text: To carry out this Act, there is authorized to be appropriated to the Secretary of Health and Human Services $5,000,000 for the period of fiscal years 2023 through 2026.
